docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Legislature adjourned today after one of its longest and most contentious sessions in memory, finally enacting the long-delayed state budget and passing bills that would protect patients in managed care plans and authorize a $1.75 billion environmental bond act. Following a longstanding Albany tradition, last-minute dickering on major legislation continued through Friday night and into the morning, as negotiators worked frantically to draft and print bills so that legislators could leave town today.

headline.main: Legislature Passes a Budget, Finally Ending a Long Session

docs.lead_paragraph: LIDO BEACH in the 50's and 60's was synonymous with private beach clubs. There were five south of Lido Boulevard -- the Colony Club, the Coral Reef, the Monaco, the Sands and the Shelborne. They drew thousands of day-trippers who arrived early to use the cabanas, beaches, pools and courts and stayed late for the restaurants and nightclubs with big-name entertainers. By the 60's, as people left the city for the suburbs, the private beach clubs on the Atlantic Ocean began to lose their popularity. They were replaced by condominiums slotted along a string of public parks and beaches.

docs.lead_paragraph: ST. VINCENT'S Medical Center in Bridgeport, the PHP Healthcare Corporation of Reston, Va., and hundreds of Fairfield County health professionals have joined forces in a new company called Connecticut Health Enterprise. At a time when the rules of the health-care system are increasingly set by cost-conscious insurance companies, officials of the new partnership say their venture will return authority to doctors. What makes Connecticut Health Enterprise different, say its founders, is the participation of PHP Healthcare, with its computer system and health-care management program.

headline.main: Doctors at Work To Regain Some Power

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN asked in kindergarten to discuss his father around Father's Day last month, Nicholas Oehler said, ''Some day I hope to run with my dad.'' Although that might seem an ordinary goal for any 5-year-old, the circumstances are far from ordinary. Nicholas's dad is Dennis Oehler, the first disabled athlete to run a 100-meter dash in less than 12 seconds. Mr. Oehler, whom some fans have called the world's fastest human being on one leg, also has held world records in 200- and 400-meter races and the long jump.

headline.main: Fighting Notions About the Disabled and Setting World Records

docs.lead_paragraph: FACED with increasing costs and fewer inpatient stays, many hospitals and doctors are joining together to take a more active role in how health care is provided. Instead of being controlled by insurance companies, they are aiming to establish their own managed-care companies. ''Hospitals are looking at ways of reinventing themselves and participating in the health care market,'' says Karen Smigel, a financial examiner with the Connecticut Insurance Department. She says she gets three to four inquiries each week from hospitals interested in starting an H.M.O., but estimates that only one in 100 files an application. ''An H.M.O. is a different mindset,'' she said. ''It's not as easy at it looks. You have to interact with other hospitals not as a competitor but as a provider in your network.'' The first hospital-owned H.M.O. in the state was Suburban Health Plan, established in 1988 by the Griffin Health Services Corporation and Avanti Health System of Texas. Griffin became sole owner of the H.M.O. in December, buying out New York Life (which had purchased the Sanus Corporation, which had earlier purchased Avanti). Suburban maintained a stable enrollment of around 2,800 members, primarily in the Naugatuck Valley area, until January of 1995. Through a stronger marketing effort -- aimed at small businesses and individuals -- membership has grown to 5,300. More than 1,000 doctors and three other hospitals participate in the plan. ''We are an experiment that, I think, has an opportunity to make it,'' says Harry Blair, a consultant with Creative Health Concepts in New York City, who works part-time as the executive director of Suburban. ''Insurance, as originally constituted, was to help you when you got sick,'' he says. ''The H.M.O. tries to deal with the patient before they get sick, through paying for preventive services and developing wellness programs. The H.M.O. says if you do these things, you will not get sick, or you won't be as sick. It's more patient focused.''

headline.main: The Changing Ways of Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: THE incredible shrinking Republican Congressional agenda, hailed in January as a rare opportunity to test competing political philosophies so the voters could have a choice on Election Day, is now down to spending bills, welfare, the minimum wage increase, safe drinking water, gay marriages and a few maybes. New curbs on illegal immigrants and portable health insurance coverage are the most prominent of the problematic measures Republicans still also hope to pass. Each has bipartisan support in principle but lots of difficulties in practice. But even if those bills, and welfare reform, make it to President Clinton's desk and he signs them, the 104th Congress will end up with a rather puny record of laws enacted.

headline.main: The Nation;The Revolution Is on Hold

docs.lead_paragraph: BY all outward appearances, the Muscoot Inn, an eating establishment off the junction of Routes 35 and 100 here, has always been easy to miss. The weather-beaten diner has a decidedly ramshackle look. Inside the wooden floors are slanted, the doors slightly aplomb. But loyal patrons of the restaurant known affectionately as the Muscoot have always liked it that way. The Muscoot has always been more than an affordable place to eat with good food and crisp, thin-crust pizza, its supporters say. The 12-table restaurant had a cozy feel, and the one-hour waits at peak times were made easier by the ambiance at the bar. And like Cheers, made famous in a television series, it was the kind of place where friendships ran deep and everybody knew everybody else. Customers who patronized the Muscoot in earlier years as a pizza and wedge shop and families who discovered the expanded menu in recent years referred to it as ''our place.''

headline.main: Diner Destined to Close Is Rescued by Two Longtime Patrons

docs.lead_paragraph: TO see it now, one would never know that the Shenorock Shore Club was virtually destroyed by the nor'easter of 1992. On a recent sultry evening, as members celebrated its 50th anniversary, the place was the essence of polished gentility: the pale gray clubhouse with freshly painted white trim was perfectly picturesque against the summer dusk; on the veranda, with its awning-shaded tables and rows of potted red geraniums, sun-tanned men and women sipped drinks and nibbled shrimp while admiring the view of Long Island Sound. Yet it was this same body of water that three and a half years ago rushed up the beach, turned the free-standing cabanas, in the words of one member, into "floating boxes" and filled the clubhouse with several feet of ruinous water. On that winter day, members -- many having been summoned by spouses on their cellular phones -- came to the club and cried.

headline.main: The View From: Rye;Neither Storm Nor Fire Can Defeat Shenorock
